From the Massachusetts Journal.

SIR A very common error prevails, that the
cause Of MIR. Adams is weak and unpopular in this
State In truth, the friends OF the Administrator
are just beginning to discover their numbers and
strength. BY wise suggestion OF very sensible
and spirited writer the signature of' Farmer,"
whose circulation has been extensive, the people
holding meetings in the different counties, to send
delcgaes to General ConveHton at Richmond, to
form an electoral ticket. Spotsylyania with great
pronpIness and zeal. embraced the proposal, and, at
a meeting respectable and numerous. held In Fred
k,buig, chose distinguished fellow-citizens,
Judge Brooke and Col. Mercer, delegates. Notices
are given for the like meetings to be held in this
county and The adjoining, Stafford, both decidedly
friendly to Mr. Adams, some time in the present or
ensuing month. Fredericksburg is the residence OF
several Of the noisy champions OF the Opposition,
and was thought to be tneir strong hold but the
late proceedings must disappont the hopes of their
strenuous advoe ates.


II the impression is general that Virginia is un-


friendly to the Administration, there can be no great
wonder. nor is it difficult to be accounted for. The
Opposition is characersticaly clamorous, and that
trait probably distinguishes them more particularly
in this State whether figuring in the editorial columns
of paper or calculating praises of the Hero in a
tavern hall. he friends of the Administration, on


me contrary, relying the honest integrity of their
sentiments. more modest and Silent for 1t would
be vain as dangerous for them to raise the still
. small voice of reason amid the whirwind of passion
and vocerous catrarauiings of the infuriaed Jack
u sonites BY this means, their numbers and pow
e cr have heretofore been conceaed-,hey have been
precluded the opportunity of acting in concert and
y the world and themselves been imposed upon by
(. the belief of their want Of strength. But truth
r. is omnpotent, and will prevail and it is becoming


daily more evident that the interests Of Mr.. Adams


are great in this supposed recreant State. They


are taking steps firmly and independently to express
their feelings and publish them to their sister States
e. They are no longer to be hoodwinked by an Enqur
p or ragooned out of their opinions by Telegraph
IS Give the people but light, and they ask no more
nd Indeed in the nature things, 1t is indispensable t
y the formation of correct opinions, whether in moral
W politics and where is left free to comba
nat error. the friends of truth need never to fear Blu
how can this when the system that is pui

BALTIMORE, 9th Oct. 1927.
SIR: We have been appointed. by an assembage
OF our feow-citizens, to address you on their be-
hai and to express to you their earnest desire that
you would consent to remain in the City of Balti-
more, for few days, On your return to the Seat Of
Government.


In making the request we feel assured that ",
only ao Justice to our telow-ctizens, who are anx

LETTER OF INVITATION.
40 JoHS QrINcy ADAMS,
President of the o. States,

jy placed hin above the want winch mas pursueu I
the old age of too many Of our veterans. but was
,he foundation of subsequent opuence. The IN
considerable town which at the close Of the war,
,a,nb.eaI less that ten thousand souls. has since,
,n!ler the influences Of that liberty which he aided
IN asserting. expanded to the city Of seventy-two
thousand embracing by degrees within its growing
streets, The venerable shades which sheltered the
retired soldier. Instead of the deep forest, the
s,rccpitous hills, and the unwhoesome marshes, in
which commerce tempted our ancestors toplace them
selves, his mansion now overiooks a large and busy
mart of men, Of which every rising dome and tow
er is in some sort monument of his own successful
patriotism. An old age warmed and enlivened byl
such topics of grateful reflection IS the most envIa-
BILE of the conditions of human life, as well as all
object of the utmost veneratun Il regard. Towards
the soldier of the Cowpens this regard was felt,
not only by his immediate neighbours and by MS tor
7ner companions in arms, but by the most eminent
worthless of his day. The.' Father ol his Country
in more than one letter. expressed to him his comb
dence and esteem. In one, he regrets Colonel How
ards declialng to accepts post, as loss both tol
himself and to the public and requests in another,
the nterposition of gentleman in Pmiadeiph'a- 70
;intace the Colonel's acceptance. "Had your mcli-
nations, ,says Washington, in his letter to Col How
ard, 'aud private pursuits permitted you to take
the Office that was offered you, it would have been
a very plersilg circumstance to 0e, and am pur-
Suaded, as | observed to you on former occasion.
a very acceptable one to the public. But the reasons
which YOU have assigned for not doing SO. carry
conviction along with them and mast hoceocr rciuc-
tant'y, be submitted 10.


At his death, Colonel Howard was, we believe,
the highest officer in rank in the Continental Ser
vice, except General Lafayette. He himself dit
not know of any other,-General Sumter, who i
still living, having been an officer Of militla ant
without any Continental commission.


The character of Col. Howard partook OF the
strength of the school in which it was trained
His first lessons, received in the thoughtful Infancy
of our country had imbucd his mind with the nerv
ous and unadorned wisdom of the time His man
hood, hardened in the stormy season OF the Revo
luton, was taught patience by privation, by vrtu
and common example By his worth he had won tn
painful station of champion who was not to b
spared from the field Of action, and his sense OF dut
was too peremptory to permit him to refuse the cor
slant acquisitions of this perilous honor. In tn
camp, therefore, amidst the accidents of war, hi
moral constitution acquired the hardihood, and hi
arm the prowess, of ancient chivalry. tie reach
ed in safety the close Of that anxious struggle, wit
mind braced by calamity, and lanillarlsed to grea
achievements. 1t threw him on the world in tn
vigour Of his days. gifted with the qualities of PRO
vdent brave, temperate and iniexlble patriot. Tn
characteristics thus acquired, never faded IN subse
qhent life. Pursued by an unusual share Of homo
and regard as founder of the liberties of his cou,
try, he never begIed by the homage it attrac
ed. fortune that might be deemed princely. WI
never used to increase the lustre Of his station,
the weight of hi. authority, but proiusely di
pensed in public benefactons, and acts of mun!l
cence. With the aurenlents of power continual
soliciting his ambition, he never threw himself int
the public service but when the emergencies of til
state left him no privilege of refusal. Under sue
conditions only he administered the grave duties
Office, with an integrity wisdom and justice, TIL
gave to his opinions authentic and absolute swa


Amidst the frantic agitaons OF party, which for
series OF years conyulsed the nation, he almost alol
in his generation won the universal conidenc
The most inveterate popular prcjndices seemed


yield to the afectionate conviction OF his impregn
Bile honesty, his unbending love OF country, ~
that personal independence which neither party-ze
could warp from its course, passion subee
nor faction alarm and in their htteres exacerb
tions his fellow citizens of all ranks turned towaI
him as to a fountain of undehled patriotism. IMP
vate life he was distinguished for the amenity of h
manners, his hospitality and his extensive and u.
inl knowledge. fle possessed a memory painful
minute; and love Of information that never SUI
under the labor of cquisitIon.-Thcsc iacult
rendered hun, perhaps, the most accurate rcpos


ny OF the history this own tlme in this or any 9th
country His habits of life were contemplate,
cautious, scrupuously just, and regulated by
strctest method


Few men have enjoyed more enviable lot


youth distinguished in the field his age in the CO,
Gil, and every period solaced by the attachment
friends. Afiluent in fortune, as rich in public


gard, and blessed in his domestic and personal


sociatlons he has gided away from the small bant
his compatrios, as full ofhonors as of years. I


example of such citizen is legacy to his count
gilmore worth than the precepts Of anage.

PHILADELPHIA. 18th Oct. 1897.
SIRs: On my passage through New York, your
very obiiyng letter, of the 9th instant, was put in
to my hands, while under an impression, derived
from communications received at the same time, that
the public service required my return to Washing
ton, without a moment of delay. On my arrival IN
this City, yesterday, with the intention Of immedi-
atey proceeding, u the expectation of reaching the
Seat of Government this morning. received inlor-1
nation from which was enabled to manifest my
grateful sense Of the kind attentions of my fellow
citizens here aud at Baltimore, by postponing, for
two days, my return to Washington.
!, therefore, remained here yesterday. and propose
to continue my journey this day 10 Baltimore and to
pass the day there on Monday. can have nohigl,-
qualification than that of meeting you there, and
those OF my iellow-Citizens, at whose desire you
have addressed to this invitation, with all others
who may incline to exchange with me friendly sal
utatOn.


10 that purpose hope to devote the day of Mon
day next, and avail myself Of this opportunity to as
you, that it language is inadequate to express
my sens!biity to the favorable estimate you have
made Of my public services. your generous confidence





devotion to the interests and welfare of our common
country, of your friend and ieow-ctizens
i JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.

as to afford his fellow citizens, generally, an oppur

alarm having spread the governor ct Illinois ordered
ant the state militia and, at the same time Col.
Atkinson nut in motion the troops under his
charge and intelligence OF these movements
was, doubtless Immediately conveyed to the hostile


tribes. The effect was soon seen. AltnouSh, IN
their previous negotiations with the Indians, the


commissioners of the United States had been unable


to bring the chiefs to proper sense of their mscon-


duet and to accede to the demand that the perpera


tors of the outrages should be given up, no sooner


were the Indians aware Of the fact that the military
Iof the United States was directed against them, to
enforce the demand of the commissioners. than


they instantly brought in the individuals VINO had
been guilty of the murders, and delivered them up


to the persons authorized to receive them. Inc


ceremonies accompanying this act Of justice are


described as very solemn and impressive. One oi
| the criminals advanced, bearing red flag, and the


other Il white one, accompanied by upwards ot a
hundred chiefs, and singing the death song, deli


vered themselves up to explate their onence WIN


their own lives. in obedience to the great precept OF


our religion, which inculcatcs-" he that sheddelh


mans blood, by man shall his blood be shed. " Eve
ry concession which was required OF the Indians


having been made. military operations are, OF course


at an end, and tranquility is restored. We are


ead that this affair has thus terminated without the
Shedding of blood, which must have ensued if the


Indians had persisted in their refusal to surrender
thp ,lenuuents. An Indian war would excite grea


regret ip the breast of every friend of humanity


for. although the evils to would be confined tt


the injuries done to our feow-citlzens on the iron


tiers no one could contemplate the destruction whic'
must be thus brought on these poor and scattere'
remnants Of the original possessors Of the soil with
out an intense feeling of pity. It is much NOR
! agreeable task to reform these miserable tribes b.
!" u mdness, than by the sword and we sincerel
:. hone the terror which seems to have been no'
i stricken into them by the prompt measures take


by oul government to secure retrDut!on, WIN nav
the effect of forever preventing any indications
: host,lit, on the part of the Indian tribes hereafter

preached in the spring by the Argus and impressed
upon the republican party, as the only safe and pe-
coming course for them, was, as we then described
it, mere cover to divert public attention from the
Presidential question, in order that Mr.. Van Buren
and his tools might work without being suspected,
and assidueusly prepare matters, though IN me
dark, for an ultimate declaration in favour of the
candidate of the south. 1t was an order from the
chief manager to all and each of his ege adherents


comprising about as rotten portion OF the poPu-


aton of this great State any in it, and therefore,
perhaps the better fitted for the unscrupuous sort
OF work they are called upon to perform, to ap-
stain from forming or expressing any opinion OF
their own, as to the candidate to be supported tor
the Presidency, until his arrangements should be
completed, and his directions should in consequence
issue to determine their choice :. and the order
was obcyed. The Argus had no opinion The.
echoes Of the Argus had no opinion the mere poll
tical partzan, however he might previously have
felt or spoken-began to have opinon--nien,
even of grade higher than this--.men of sone
substance and understanding and in other affairs
of vigor of character, talked obscurely and doubt
ingly. ''They had not thought about IT, it
would be time enough year hence''- they haa
no fault to find with the present administration but
there was no use IN committing ones self or prema'
turely exciting neat ana luminosity. .-Language ike
this was heard from the lips of persons, who were
not wont IN other matters to halt, procrastinate


and in all cases it to be traced to the one great


fear, OF being denounced by Mr.. Van Burcn and his
press, as ieteraists or Clintonians Chat however,
nowadays, is merit. with the Senator and his de.
pendants, or as violating ''the usages Of the repub-
iican party )" and thus by the audacious presumP-
ton OF some half-dozen men at Al'any-capable,
artful, and ever at work, check was put upon the
thoughts, gag pnt into the mouths of thousands


until this Numerically and morally speaking, little

upeigned respect for your public services, and ther
warm appreciation o. o.. 'ne enllsntened pollay when
ernmeht since you have presided over it.
Permit us, therefore, respectfully. but earnestly
to request you to soourn in City as long the
public business will allow you, and thus enable rs tc
pay to the Chief Magistrate of the Nation. those
marks Prospect which sojustly due to one whust
life has been devoted to the service of his country
We have the honor to be, Sir, with great respect
your most obedient servants,
/ WIN. PATTERSON,


VIM. MCDONALD,
SOLOMON ETrING,
LUKE TIERNAN.


DAVID HOFFMAN,


RICHARD b. MAGRUDER.

LINK. FiD.
We have understood that there was great trep-
da,on and running up and down among the Jackso-
mans Of this city.


We were not surprised therefore, when gentle
nan stepped into our office, and requested us TO
publish the following spirlt-strrng notice-it was
addressed, by mistake, presume, to friend OF
the Administration.


1.-The jackson County and Ward Committees
will meet at the Statesman Office, Congress-sreet,
on Friday Evening, Oct 12th on business of the ut
most importdnce' BY order Of the Chairman.
Signed by the Secretary.


The words italicsed were so in the printed copy
and they appeur portentous Our friends need not
however, be alarmed The jackson men have nc
business " of importance here. There are but
or 800 Of them IN Massachusetts, and those are con
fined to Bostoa In the country there are none
and the city there about enough to fill the OF
fees which Gen. jackson is expected to turn tn
present lncutnbents out OF.

full articles.headline:
AFFAIRS IN VIRGINIA.
Fran the National Journak
full articles.article:
Extract ofa letter to the Editor, daled King George,


pa. Oct 2, 1927.


SIR A very common error prevails, that the
cause Of MIR. Adams is weak and unpopular in this
State In truth, the friends OF the Administrator
are just beginning to discover their numbers and
strength. BY wise suggestion OF very sensible
and spirited writer the signature of' Farmer,"
whose circulation has been extensive, the people
holding meetings in the different counties, to send
delcgaes to General ConveHton at Richmond, to
form an electoral ticket. Spotsylyania with great
pronpIness and zeal. embraced the proposal, and, at
a meeting respectable and numerous. held In Fred
k,buig, chose distinguished fellow-citizens,
Judge Brooke and Col. Mercer, delegates. Notices
are given for the like meetings to be held in this
county and The adjoining, Stafford, both decidedly
friendly to Mr. Adams, some time in the present or
ensuing month. Fredericksburg is the residence OF
several Of the noisy champions OF the Opposition,
and was thought to be tneir strong hold but the
late proceedings must disappont the hopes of their
strenuous advoe ates.


II the impression is general that Virginia is un-


friendly to the Administration, there can be no great
wonder. nor is it difficult to be accounted for. The
Opposition is characersticaly clamorous, and that
trait probably distinguishes them more particularly
in this State whether figuring in the editorial columns
of paper or calculating praises of the Hero in a
tavern hall. he friends of the Administration, on


me contrary, relying the honest integrity of their
sentiments. more modest and Silent for 1t would
be vain as dangerous for them to raise the still
. small voice of reason amid the whirwind of passion
and vocerous catrarauiings of the infuriaed Jack
u sonites BY this means, their numbers and pow
e cr have heretofore been conceaed-,hey have been
precluded the opportunity of acting in concert and
y the world and themselves been imposed upon by
(. the belief of their want Of strength. But truth
r. is omnpotent, and will prevail and it is becoming


daily more evident that the interests Of Mr.. Adams


are great in this supposed recreant State. They


are taking steps firmly and independently to express
their feelings and publish them to their sister States
e. They are no longer to be hoodwinked by an Enqur
p or ragooned out of their opinions by Telegraph
IS Give the people but light, and they ask no more
nd Indeed in the nature things, 1t is indispensable t
y the formation of correct opinions, whether in moral
W politics and where is left free to comba
nat error. the friends of truth need never to fear Blu
how can this when the system that is pui
he sued, continues ?-wAen the minds of the public ar

full articles.article:
Races.--The purse yesterday of S3OO--three mile
heats--we understand was finely contested. The
first heat was won by MIR. EIiotts horse Echard iii
the following two heats by Mr.. Coles Sports.
man, who Of course took the purse


For the purse OF this day, 5000, and two mile
heats, the following horses have entered Mr. Van
Rants horse Jack ON the Green Mr.. Stevens mare
l.alla Rookh. Mr.. Coles horse Fox: and Mr.
mare Lady Hunter.


At ~ O'Clock. previous to the commencement nj
the races on Thursday. the celebrated horses Ecps,
Il Henry were sold at auction, on the ground. !,
front Of the judges box, by Mr. James Seton. The,
were both purchased by Mr.. Ludlow. Of Clayerack
in this state. The former at Sso5o; the latter

full articles.headline: From the National Journal.
full articles.article:
DOMESTIC. During the last week intelligence
has been received which relieves us from any appre


henson that an Indian war will take place. 1t ap-
pears that some OF the tribes, the Winnebanoes cs
pecally, have been for some time dlscunten,rd and


re,tul and it is probable hat the outrages recently
COMMITTED on the frontier would have been Inllow


ed by more serious assaults on our citizens in that
quarter, but for the prompt measures of defence
resOrted to by the civil and military officers. The

continually subject to the influence Ct lset,a. 4,
fo nolitica dou,nas and grataitOus asscituls Vt ri
tors who layis, untruths to the people as essential
to keep alive their faith, as daily meat and duuk 10
nourish and sustain their corporeal frames In this
county, am glad, however, to say, that dis.
nositon prevails to investigate, every man for him.
sec and to rey on the ipse dirit Of man. however
famed for truth-not even the scrupulous and vera.
cious Duff Green or Thomas Rtchie-Ihus vast
and laudable revolution has been the consequence.
The change public opinion here has undergone,
| wonderful and extensive, and may be dated from
the appearance of Mr. Buchanans statement. /


was at the Court House Of this county shortly afte,


its arrival, and the admiration expressed Of Alr.


Ca, IS innocence, and the Indignation at the mali
cious attempt to deiame him, we're loud and warm.
The friends Of the Hero were emphatcay chopals
and gentleman whom approached, and expressed


nv satisfaction to, the unequlv"ca acqultta of Mr.
Ciay, & my hope that General Jackson would now be


"a rood as his word toacknowledge thathe had done
4 that great and injured injustice, REPLIED " that
the General was never otherwise than magnannUus
and would, no doubt, redeem his promise" But
his friend had Overraed his virtues magDanlhity,
, is not conspicuous among them, or he would, with


a!acrity, hasten 10 confess the wrong he has done
e him. IT,
The aspect of affairs is bright and Aattering, and
the steps now taking to ascertain, more certainly,
the voice of Virginia, will result favouraby 10 .the
/; Administration and strike with asonish,nent and
0 dsmay the Opposition ranks sand their attempts to
j. ritlicue it are vain. Wonderful unanimty prevails
upon the subject 1t has the support of able, finn,
consistent, honest, patriotic Vrginans and put in
+ opposite scales the ably edited Wing, Of Richmond
G can and will give it support that will outweigh all
y the bitter condemnation sneers and scurty OF a
neighboring print, that utters fasehood sch fear
" and trembing* 1t is, further, matter OF pride and
N graduation to find that those who averse from the
,a blind devotion manifested to the Hero are men
Of whose education, Responsibility and ind ependepce,
r. give their opinions weight and consideration, and
will be of value in the coming elections; while, OIL


the contrary, those who are most distinguished and
. clamorous in the Opposition, are possessed nellhe


of influence, of character. or many of them, OF free


hold qualification. | speak this with many excep
)" tons for there are, among the friends OF Genera


Jackson, gentlemen Of the highest responsibility
u but they are taw in comparison with what the Admin
o. straon numbers. 1t is certainly the case IN kll


George, and, as far as my acquaintance extends, Il
e. Stafford and Spotsyvania


TO think, Sir, we may now congratulate ourselyt
AS and the country or the prospect of the triumph
Of liberal principles in the Old dominion. This Stat


80 long famed for the virtue of her citizens, bot
,es in public and in private fefor the superior intel
et gence and rmness Of her public men, and the zc
a. ous support she has heretofore given to all measur


of general interest, st,-cannot, will not, now pro-


recreant. Though she may for a time be mlsled
w. the evil counsel OF some of her degenerate sons,
~ majority will be found sufficiently flal and ate
no tionate to lend her vrtuous aid.-Thoush she IN
for time receive the eprous distment of corrupt
on in her ear, and discard distinguished son from
No bosom; yet she can never prove unnatural: and
oc. day is at hand, when the affections implanted in
the mothers breast will be predominant, and she
glory to receive into her arms, and embrace, W


maternal warmth and feeling, her injured SON.


is needless to say aude to Henry Clay. Al


virginian feel pride at being native Of the sa
'ge. one found 50 lost to sense of his hgh merit.
-, would not consider that his State of nativity shot
.h ie feel honored in having an opportunity Of honor
ei's him.


ion


and n. Ve.;+o sans ne,r.,-ss T,r,tb ,,tboaa far'

full articles.headline:
LETTER OF INVITATION.
40 JoHS QrINcy ADAMS,
President of the o. States,
full articles.article:
BALTIMORE, 9th Oct. 1927.
SIR: We have been appointed. by an assembage
OF our feow-citizens, to address you on their be-
hai and to express to you their earnest desire that
you would consent to remain in the City of Balti-
more, for few days, On your return to the Seat Of
Government.


In making the request we feel assured that ",
only ao Justice to our telow-ctizens, who are anx
lpus as they have been on the several occasions whe
you have heretofore passed through their City, t
have an opportunity Afforded them Vi teslifyiry thei

jy placed hin above the want winch mas pursueu I
the old age of too many Of our veterans. but was
,he foundation of subsequent opuence. The IN
considerable town which at the close Of the war,
,a,nb.eaI less that ten thousand souls. has since,
,n!ler the influences Of that liberty which he aided
IN asserting. expanded to the city Of seventy-two
thousand embracing by degrees within its growing
streets, The venerable shades which sheltered the
retired soldier. Instead of the deep forest, the
s,rccpitous hills, and the unwhoesome marshes, in
which commerce tempted our ancestors toplace them
selves, his mansion now overiooks a large and busy
mart of men, Of which every rising dome and tow
er is in some sort monument of his own successful
patriotism. An old age warmed and enlivened byl
such topics of grateful reflection IS the most envIa-
BILE of the conditions of human life, as well as all
object of the utmost veneratun Il regard. Towards
the soldier of the Cowpens this regard was felt,
not only by his immediate neighbours and by MS tor
7ner companions in arms, but by the most eminent
worthless of his day. The.' Father ol his Country
in more than one letter. expressed to him his comb
dence and esteem. In one, he regrets Colonel How
ards declialng to accepts post, as loss both tol
himself and to the public and requests in another,
the nterposition of gentleman in Pmiadeiph'a- 70
;intace the Colonel's acceptance. "Had your mcli-
nations, ,says Washington, in his letter to Col How
ard, 'aud private pursuits permitted you to take
the Office that was offered you, it would have been
a very plersilg circumstance to 0e, and am pur-
Suaded, as | observed to you on former occasion.
a very acceptable one to the public. But the reasons
which YOU have assigned for not doing SO. carry
conviction along with them and mast hoceocr rciuc-
tant'y, be submitted 10.


At his death, Colonel Howard was, we believe,
the highest officer in rank in the Continental Ser
vice, except General Lafayette. He himself dit
not know of any other,-General Sumter, who i
still living, having been an officer Of militla ant
without any Continental commission.


The character of Col. Howard partook OF the
strength of the school in which it was trained
His first lessons, received in the thoughtful Infancy
of our country had imbucd his mind with the nerv
ous and unadorned wisdom of the time His man
hood, hardened in the stormy season OF the Revo
luton, was taught patience by privation, by vrtu
and common example By his worth he had won tn
painful station of champion who was not to b
spared from the field Of action, and his sense OF dut
was too peremptory to permit him to refuse the cor
slant acquisitions of this perilous honor. In tn
camp, therefore, amidst the accidents of war, hi
moral constitution acquired the hardihood, and hi
arm the prowess, of ancient chivalry. tie reach
ed in safety the close Of that anxious struggle, wit
mind braced by calamity, and lanillarlsed to grea
achievements. 1t threw him on the world in tn
vigour Of his days. gifted with the qualities of PRO
vdent brave, temperate and iniexlble patriot. Tn
characteristics thus acquired, never faded IN subse
qhent life. Pursued by an unusual share Of homo
and regard as founder of the liberties of his cou,
try, he never begIed by the homage it attrac
ed. fortune that might be deemed princely. WI
never used to increase the lustre Of his station,
the weight of hi. authority, but proiusely di
pensed in public benefactons, and acts of mun!l
cence. With the aurenlents of power continual
soliciting his ambition, he never threw himself int
the public service but when the emergencies of til
state left him no privilege of refusal. Under sue
conditions only he administered the grave duties
Office, with an integrity wisdom and justice, TIL
gave to his opinions authentic and absolute swa


Amidst the frantic agitaons OF party, which for
series OF years conyulsed the nation, he almost alol
in his generation won the universal conidenc
The most inveterate popular prcjndices seemed


yield to the afectionate conviction OF his impregn
Bile honesty, his unbending love OF country, ~
that personal independence which neither party-ze
could warp from its course, passion subee
nor faction alarm and in their htteres exacerb
tions his fellow citizens of all ranks turned towaI
him as to a fountain of undehled patriotism. IMP
vate life he was distinguished for the amenity of h
manners, his hospitality and his extensive and u.
inl knowledge. fle possessed a memory painful
minute; and love Of information that never SUI
under the labor of cquisitIon.-Thcsc iacult
rendered hun, perhaps, the most accurate rcpos


ny OF the history this own tlme in this or any 9th
country His habits of life were contemplate,
cautious, scrupuously just, and regulated by
strctest method


Few men have enjoyed more enviable lot


youth distinguished in the field his age in the CO,
Gil, and every period solaced by the attachment
friends. Afiluent in fortune, as rich in public


gard, and blessed in his domestic and personal


sociatlons he has gided away from the small bant
his compatrios, as full ofhonors as of years. I


example of such citizen is legacy to his count
gilmore worth than the precepts Of anage.


-@E;o: .: o5Ezn--


BAIT. Oct. 15.-Tisa Of The President qf tht


States,-Presient ApAMs reached this City


terday morning, in the steam boat from the 4


ward. and has taken lodgings at the City liz

full articles.headline: PRESIDENTS ANSWER.
full articles.article:
PRESIDENTS ANSWER.
Mersrs WM. PATTERSON, w. McDoNALp, Solo
MON ETrING, LUXE TIERNAN, DAVID HOFFMAN,
RICHARD b. MAGnuDER, Baltimore.


PHILADELPHIA. 18th Oct. 1897.
SIRs: On my passage through New York, your
very obiiyng letter, of the 9th instant, was put in
to my hands, while under an impression, derived
from communications received at the same time, that
the public service required my return to Washing
ton, without a moment of delay. On my arrival IN
this City, yesterday, with the intention Of immedi-
atey proceeding, u the expectation of reaching the
Seat of Government this morning. received inlor-1
nation from which was enabled to manifest my
grateful sense Of the kind attentions of my fellow
citizens here aud at Baltimore, by postponing, for
two days, my return to Washington.
!, therefore, remained here yesterday. and propose
to continue my journey this day 10 Baltimore and to
pass the day there on Monday. can have nohigl,-
qualification than that of meeting you there, and
those OF my iellow-Citizens, at whose desire you
have addressed to this invitation, with all others
who may incline to exchange with me friendly sal
utatOn.


10 that purpose hope to devote the day of Mon
day next, and avail myself Of this opportunity to as
you, that it language is inadequate to express
my sens!biity to the favorable estimate you have
made Of my public services. your generous confidence





devotion to the interests and welfare of our common
country, of your friend and ieow-ctizens
i JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.
We are requested to state, that the President.
having been informed of the death Of our lamented
fellow citizen, Col. John Eager Howard. and of the
arrangements made for his nerment, expressed his
desire to attend the funeral, in manifestation of his
respect for the memory of the deceased He has al
tlSnc tod in,
as to afford his fellow citizens, generally, an oppur
tunlty Of visiting HIM.


New ORLEANS, SEPT. l5.-'rhe Mississippi is fail
ing slowly. aud was. yesterday afternoon, ten feet
i've inches below hsh-waier mark. The we4thei.
since our last has been dry, cool, and pleasant UuI
5 cty,genera; speaking, i, healthy, yet not free o
bilious and yellow fever, which makes it unsafe
: for those who have left, to return Immediately.

:, board resided South of the Delaware
y One OF the above passengers, in pursuing hi
T. Tourney to Washington in the stage related the abov
~ occurrence to the passengers, who at once thoug
~ generally strangers to each other also proposed
